original_summary: #Person1# asks Mr. Snow about the attack. Mr. Snow left his office at about 9:44 and got hit when walking to his car but didn't see the attacker.

transformed_conversations.personal_summary:
Here's a summary of your interactions with Mr. Snow regarding the attack investigation, dating back to early May:

You first interviewed Mr. Snow on May 3rd, the day after he was attacked leaving his office. He provided initial details, like leaving around 9:44pm and being hit on the head by an attacker in a stocking mask. You followed up a week later to clarify some inconsistencies in his story. As the investigation continued through May and June, you stayed in touch, probing for more details and updates on his condition. A major development came in mid-June when security camera footage corroborated parts of his account. Your exchanges tapered off for a few weeks until earlier this month, when the attacker was finally apprehended. Throughout this process over nearly 3 months, you developed a rapport with Mr. Snow and a clearer picture of that night's events, though some questions still remain. The upcoming trial should hopefully bring closure and resolution to this disturbing incident.

messages.content: You: Mr. Snow, thanks for meeting with me. I know this isn't easy, but I need to ask you some questions about the attack last night. What time did you leave your office?
Mr. Snow: It was about 9:44pm. I remember looking at my watch right before locking up.
You: Okay, and what happened next? Did you see the attacker at all?

Mr. Snow: No, he had a stocking over his head. I was just walking to my car and suddenly got hit from behind. Next thing I knew I was waking up in the hospital with a broken leg. Apparently the paramedics dropped me loading me in the ambulance.
You: I'm sorry to hear that. Don't worry, we'll get to the bottom of this. Get some rest for now and let me know if you remember anything else.

You: Hi Mr. Snow, just wanted to follow up on a couple things from your statement last week. You said you left at 9:44, but one of your coworkers thought they saw you around 10pm. Any chance you left later than you thought?
Mr. Snow: No, I'm positive it was 9:44. I had been watching the clock, eager to get home. Maybe Bill was confused or saw someone else?

You: Possibly. I'll check with him again. Also, the hospital said your leg fracture was from a fall, not a direct hit. I know you were hazy after the attack, but you're sure you didn't fall or trip at any point?
Mr. Snow: It's still a bit of a blur, but I don't think so? I just remember the sharp pain in my head, then waking up injured. You don't think I'm making this up, do you??
You: Not at all, just trying to get all the facts straight. Sit tight, we'll figure this out. Let me know if anything else comes to mind.

You: Some good news in your case, Mr. Snow. Security cameras from the parking garage confirm someone fleeing the scene around 9:50pm that night, matching the attacker's description. Looks like he followed you out from the building.
Mr. Snow: That's a relief, I was starting to doubt myself. Did you get a good look at him? Any chance of ID'ing the guy?
You: The image is too grainy for facial recognition, but it's a solid lead. We'll keep pursuing other angles too, like the ongoing forensic analysis. Hang in there.
Mr. Snow: I heard through the grapevine that there was an arrest made in my case? Is that true? What can you tell me?
You: Yes, we picked up a suspect a few days ago. Forensics matched DNA from the scene and he fits the description. We're confident it's our guy but still building the case before it goes to trial.
Mr. Snow: Wow, that's amazing news! I was starting to lose hope. Do you know why he did it? Was I targeted for some reason?

You: Too soon to say, but seems like a crime of opportunity. We'll know more once we finish interrogations. Sit tight a bit longer, I'll keep you posted as court dates firm up. With any luck, this will all be behind you soon.
